key_insight: BiPS converts question-conditioned masked views into bidirectional "where-to-look" signals that steer a VLM toward the small, task-relevant visual evidence (and away from distractors), improving fine-grained multimodal reasoning while cutting inference cost.
problem_solved: Existing VLM intermediate cues miss fine-grained visual features (e.g., polylines in charts), generalize poorly across domains, and are inference-time expensive; BiPS addresses accurate, efficient, and generalizable visual guidance for reasoning.
method: Generate question-conditioned masked views that reveal candidate visual evidence while suppressing irrelevant regions.
Produce bidirectional perceptual signals (positive "look-here" maps and negative "ignore-this" maps) to shape model attention both ways during reasoning.
Inject these lightweight signals as priors (e.g., attention masks or latent tokens) into the VLM pipeline to improve fine-grained evidence capture and reduce token/computation overhead.
impact: Enables more accurate, interpretable, and compute-efficient multimodal reasoning—particularly for tasks requiring fine visual detail (charts, diagrams)—and improves cross-domain robustness for practitioners deploying VLMs under resource constraints.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: question → masked view generator → bidirectional attention maps → VLM reasoning

paper_title: See Less, See Right: Bi-directional Perceptual Shaping For Multimodal Reasoning
paper_authors: Shuoshuo Zhang, Yizhen Zhang, Jingjing Fu, Lei Song, Jiang Bian
